questions.text: A four-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with complaints of chronic diarrhea since the age of 2 years. The child was on treatment for chronic diarrhea. The developmental milestones of the child were normal.  His hematological profile was normal, tissue Transglutaminase Antibody (tTG), Ig A was negative and total IgA was within the normal range. Stool examination showed RBCs but was negative for cysts and eggs. Endoscopy was performed and the duodenal biopsy is shown below. What type of motility is exhibited by the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with the histopathology is indicative of a diagnosis of Giardiasis, caused by Giardia Lamblia which exhibits falling leaf motility.

The image shows an H&E stained section of the duodenal mucosa with giardiasis. The Giardia organisms here are seen in the bowel lumen as pale staining or translucent semicircular or crescent-shaped organisms. The intestinal villi have interepithelial lymphocytes but have a normal architecture.

Giardia lamblia, also called Giardia duodenalis, is the causative agent of giardiasis. It is a common pathogenic protozoan found in the duodenum and jejunum of humans. Infection is by the consumption of water or food contaminated with cysts, or by directly by the feco-oral route.

It is weakly pathogenic in humans. Secretory IgA and IL-6 are responsible for clearing the infection. Hence, giardiasis usually occurs in immunosuppressed, agammaglobulinemia, or malnourished individuals. The symptoms include acute or chronic diarrhea, weight loss, malaise, abdominal cramps, distension, and weakness. The stools may be watery, greasy, bulky, or foul-smelling at various times during the course of the infection.

The trophozoite is heart-shaped or pyriform-shaped with 2 equally sized nuclei and 4 pairs of flagella. It exhibits slow oscillating motility that resembles the movement of a falling leaf. 

The cyst is the infective form of the parasite and is small and oval, surrounded by a hyaline cyst wall. It has two pairs of nuclei grouped at one end. They may be found in the wet preparations of stools of infected persons.

Metronidazole and Tinidazole are the drugs of choice for the treatment of Giardiasis.

Cysts of Giardia are shown in the image below.

Related Pearl: Types of motility of microorganisms

Motility Microorganism
Darting/vibratory motility  Vibrio,Campylobacter
Swarming motility Cl. septicum, B.cereus, Proteus, some Vibrio sp
Tumbling motility  Listeria monocytogenes
Stately motility Clostridia
Spinning motility Fusobacterium gyrans
Cork-screw motility  Treponema pallidum
Falling leaf motility Giardia
Twitching motility Eikenella corrodens
Differential motility (Motility varies at different temperatures) Yersinia enterocolitica & Listeria monocytogenes
Jerky motility  Trichomonas vaginalis
Gliding motility Mycoplasma, Entamoeba
Lashing motility  Saprophytic spirochetes

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presented with progressive blurred vision, photophobia, and pain in the right eye. On examination, there was conjunctival redness, a mid-dilated pupil, and a shallow anterior chamber in the right eye. A procedure incorporates the following device to aid drainage and treat this condition. Identify the device.
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of glaucoma and the device used is an Ex-Press glaucoma implant (mini shunt).

It is a minimally invasive glaucoma surgery (MIGS) to increase aqueous drainage.

Ex-Press glaucoma implant (mini shunt), is a small stainless steel device. It is inserted under a scleral flap during a modified trabeculectomy. Mitomycin c might be used to prevent scarring. Complications such as hypotony are lower as compared to standard trabeculectomy.

 

Glaucoma drainage devices: They are devices that allow aqueous outflow by establishing a communication between the anterior chamber and sub-Tennon's space/sub-conjunctival space. 

The commonly used devices are as follows:

  • Shunts using episcleral explants

    • Ahmed glaucoma valve: A valved implant consisting of a silicone tube connected to a silicone sheet valve held together in a polypropylene body. It has a venturi valve mechanism that allows for an immediate decrease in IOP and reduced post-operative complications such as hypotony. 

    • Molteno implant: One or two polypropylene plates connected to a silicone tube. It has a larger surface area and provides long-term IOP reduction. However, risk of post-operative hypotony is high. 

    • Baerveldt implant: Large silicone plate connected to a silicone tube. It is easy to modify, flexible, and easy to implant. However, it is a bulky device and post-operative hypotony and scar deformation are associated risks. 

  • Mini-shunts 

    • Ex-Press Mini-Shunt

    • iStent®: It is a hooked titanium tube inserted into the Schlemm canal via the trabecular meshwork. More than one istent can be implanted a the same time for better control of the intraocular pressure.

The images below show the Ahmed and Molteno implants respectively.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presented with 5 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive pregnancy test. She is a known case of antiphospholipid antibody syndrome and her previous medical reports show that she had cortical vein thrombosis during the last pregnancy. Which of the following prophylactic measures should be undertaken to prevent the recurrence of such thromboembolic events?

choices.text: Close monitoring during antepartum period with postpartum heparin
Heparin throughout the pregnancy and 6 weeks postpartum
Antepartum heparin during third trimester with postpartum monitoring

questions.solution:
In this patient of antiphospholipid antibody syndrome(APLA) with prior thromboembolic events(cortical vein thrombosis), heparin should be given throughout the pregnancy and 6 weeks postpartum to prevent recurrence in subsequent pregnancies.

Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome(APLA) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies, vascular thromboses, or obstetrical complications(such as recurrent pregnancy loss and placental dysfunction leading to fetal growth restriction, stillbirth, preeclampsia, and preterm birth). Antibodies target proteins like Cardiolipin and Beta-2-glycoprotein I.

Diagnosis of APLA requires at least 1 clinical (obstetric or vascular) criterion and 1 laboratory criterion.

  • Obstetric criteria
    • One or more unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond 10 weeks or
    • Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery before 34 weeks, or
    • Three or more unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks
  • Vascular criteria: One or more episodes of arterial, venous, or small vessel thrombosis in any tissue or organ
  • Laboratory criteria include presence of:
    • Lupus anticoagulant, or
    • Anti-cardiolipin antibodies, or
    • Anti-β2 glycoprotein I antibody.

Specific therapy in pregnancy: Aspirin plus heparin therapy is the most effective regimen. Women are treated with low-dose aspirin (50 mg/day) and heparin (5,000 units SC twice daily) for up to 34 weeks. Unfractionated heparin and low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) are equally effective and safe.

Corticosteroids are used only in secondary APLA syndrome (associated with SLE) and not in primary APLA syndrome. 

Prophylaxis:

  • Women with prior thromboembolic events: Prophylactic anticoagulation throughout pregnancy and 6 weeks postpartum with either heparin is recommended. Serial sonographic assessment of fetal growth and antepartum testing should be done in the third trimester due to the risk of fetal growth abnormalities and stillbirths.
  • For women without prior thromboembolic events, acceptable regimes include:
    • Close antepartum maternal observation with or without prophylactic heparin along with postpartum anticoagulation for 4 to 6 weeks, or
    • Surveillance alone , or
    • Prophylactic heparin +low dose aspirin (if prior history of recurrent abortion or stillbirth)

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was admitted with altered sensorium, hydrophobia, and seizures after he was bitten by a stray dog 4 weeks ago. The patient passed away and an autopsy was performed. Identify the layer of the cerebellar cortex in which the pathognomic intracellular inclusion bodies are usually seen.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is that of rabies encephalitis and the pathognomic intracellular inclusion bodies (Negri bodies) are seen in Purkinje cells belonging to the Purkinje cell layer (Layer C).

The cerebellar cortex is divided into 3 layers histologically. They are:

  • Molecular layer - It is the outermost layer that contains stellate cells and basket cells, and dendrites of Purkinje cells. They receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and form inhibitory synapses on the Purkinje cells. It contains many myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibers. It appears pale on H and E staining.
  • Purkinje layer - contain the cell bodies of the Purkinje cells which are flask-shaped. Characteristics of Purkinje cells:
    • Flask-shaped, evenly spaced cells arranged in a single layer.
    • The only efferents of the cerebellar cortex.
    • A dendrite from the neck of each flask-shaped cell passes upward to the molecular layer and the axon passes down through the granular layer to the white matter.
    • Purkinje cells are inhibitory and use GABA as their neurotransmitter.
  • Granular layer - It is the innermost layer. It contains the cell bodies of the granule cells. It receives excitatory input from the mossy fibers. They end the dendrites of the granule cells and these complexes are called glomeruli. The axon from the granule cells travels to the molecular layer and bifurcates in a T-shape. These branches from the T are called parallel fibers. These parallel fibers form excitatory synapses with the Purkinje cells. The granule cells form the only excitatory neurons in the cerebellar cortex. It also contains Golgi cells that receive input from parallel fibers and mossy fibers. They send inhibitory output to the granule cells.

Rabies presents initially with fever and paraesthesia near the bite, following which the patient becomes increasingly anxious, leading to hydrophobia, delusions, and hallucinations. On microscopic examination of the brain, there is neuronal degeneration with inflammation. Negri bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, eosinophilic inclusions seen in the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and the Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. (seen below)

Related Pearl: Layers of the cerebellar cortex

The cerebellar cortex is divided into 3 layers. They are:

  • Molecular layer - It is the outermost layer. It contains stellate cells and basket cells. They receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and form inhibitory synapses on the Purkinje cells. It contains many myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibers giving it a pale appearance in H and E staining.
  • Purkinje layer - It is the middle layer. It contain flask-shaped cell bodies of Purkinje cells. Their dendrites pass into the molecular layer. The axons of the Purkinje cells passes through the granular layer into the white matter and synapses with the cerebellar nuclei.
  • Granular layer - It is the innermost layer. It contains the cell bodies of the granule cells as well as Golgi cells. It receives excitatory input from the mossy fibers. They end on the dendrites of the granule cells and these complexes are called glomeruli. The axon from the granule cells travels to the molecular layer and bifurcates in a T-shape. These branches form the T and are called parallel fibers. These parallel fibers form excitatory synapses with the Purkinje cells. The granule cells form the only excitatory neurons in the cerebellar cortex. Golgi cells receive input from parallel fibers and mossy fibers. They send inhibitory output to the granule cells.

Neurotransmitters released:

  • Stellate, basket, Golgi and Purkinje cells- GABA
  • Granule cells - Glutamate

The only output from the cerebellar cortex is inhibitory from the Purkinje cells to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with complaints of drooping of the angle of the mouth and blurred vision, redness, and pain in both eyes for the past few days. She says that over the past three months she has had a cough, mild fever, and has lost weight. Examination reveals a pulse rate of 84 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 138/76 mm of Hg, and a temperature of 99 F. The right parotid region appears swollen. There is facial asymmetry with drooping of the angle of the mouth, inability to close her right eye, and furrow her forehead on the same side. A chest X-ray is performed which reveals the findings attached below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette along with the chest X-ray finding of bilateral hilar node enlargement is strongly suggestive of Heerfordt-Waldenström syndrome or Uveo-parotid fever. It is a rare presentation of sarcoidosis, and also considered a type of neurosarcoidosis. It is characterized by-

  • Fever
  • Anterior uveitis- Presents as diffuse congestion of the conjunctival vessels with a prominent circumcorneal injection, pain, and blurred vision
  • Parotid gland enlargement- Due to a granulomatous inflammatory reaction. Cervical lymphadenopathy may also be present. 
  • Facial nerve palsy- May show epineural granulomas and perineural inflammation involving the facial nerve. 

The bilateral hilar lymph node enlargement further alludes to the diagnosis of sarcoidosis. Sarcoidosis is a systemic disease characterized by the formation of non-caseating granulomas. Patients with sarcoidosis typically present with cough, dyspnea, chest pain, fever, weight loss, arthralgias, and erythema nodosum. Few patients may have neurological involvement with facial nerve palsy being the most common manifestation. 

Diagnosis may be established based on clinical features and biopsy findings. Investigations that are generally used include-

  • Chest X-ray:

The chest radiograph is the preferred tool used to stage sarcoidosis. It depends on the lymphadenopathy and pulmonary infiltrates. The parenchymal infiltrates in sarcoidosis are predominantly seen in the upper lobe and appear as diffuse reticular infiltrates. Garland triad is a lymph node enlargement pattern seen on the chest radiographs in sarcoidosis. It involves the right paratracheal nodes, right hilar nodes, and left hilar nodes. It is also known as the 1-2-3 sign or Pawnbrokers sign. 

The staging of sarcoidosis is as below-

Stage 1 Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy (usually symmetrical); right paratracheal nodes often enlarged
Stage 2  Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and parenchymal infiltrates
Stage 3 Parenchymal infiltrates without bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy
Stage 4 Pulmonary fibrosis  
  • Biopsy: Biopsies reveal non-caseating granulomas. 
  • Gallium-67 scan:
    • Panda sign- It is due to bilateral involvement of parotid and lacrimal glands in sarcoidosis, superimposed on the normal uptake in the nasopharyngeal mucosa.
    • Lambda sign- It is seen in thoracic sarcoidosis. Bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph nodes are typically involved which can resemble the lambda symbol (λ).
  • Elevated serum ACE levels: Granulomas in sarcoidosis are known to produce ACE. 
  • Hypercalcemia may be seen, due to increased synthesis of calcitriol – 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D, by alveolar macrophages. In some patients, there may be hypercalciuria, which can lead to nephrocalcinosis.
  • Increased CD4/CD8 ratio of these increased lymphocytes in the BAL fluid. A ratio of >3.5 is strongly supportive of sarcoidosis.
  • Bronchoscopy shows the typical 'cobblestone' appearance of the mucosa.
  • Pulmonary function test shows a restrictive lung disease, with impaired gas exchange.

Treatment of Heerfordt-Waldenström syndrome is with corticosteroids, which forms the mainstay of treatment. Immunosuppressants such as mycophenolate mofetil, cyclosporine, and infliximab can be used in patients who are refractory to steroids. 

The stages of sarcoidosis are given below:

 

Other options-

Option A: Posner-Schlossmann syndrome, also called glaucomatocyclitic crisis is acute, recurrent, very mild uveitis associated with secondary glaucoma. 

Option C: Lofgren's syndrome is also a form of acute sarcoidosis presenting with erythema nodosum, arthritis, and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy.

Option D: Tolosa Hunt syndrome consists of retro-orbital or unilateral periorbital pain associated with ophthalmoparesis of the 3rd, 4th, 6th cranial nerves with pain relief after beginning corticosteroid.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is bought to the emergency department after being found in a confused state at a bus station in Kerala. He is unable to recall his name, address, spouse's name, or any other personal information. His driving license from his wallet revealed that he is from Bangalore. Further investigation revealed that he got laid off from his job two days ago. He has no history of substance abuse. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is suggestive of dissociative amnesia with a dissociative fugue. 

Dissociative amnesia is characterized by extensive and severe amnesia with an inability to recall important autobiographical information. The amnesia is predominantly retrograde with minimal anterograde amnesia. It usually follows severe emotional trauma, interpersonal conflicts, and other stressful events, such as sexual abuse, loss of a loved one, loss of livelihood, etcetera. Clinically, the presentation is quite dramatic with significant impairment in social, personal, and occupational functioning. In order for a diagnosis of dissociative amnesia to be made, it is imperative to rule out substance use, and other neurological and psychological conditions that may lead to a presentation similar to dissociative amnesia. 

It is further categorized into the following types:

  • Selective amnesia: Ability to remember some of the events occurring during a circumscribed period of time.
  • Localized amnesia: Inability to recall all events in a circumscribed period of time.
  • Generalized amnesia: Failure to recall one’s entire life.
  • Continuous amnesia: Failure to recall successive events as they occur.
  • Systematized amnesia: Amnesia for certain categories of memory, such as all memories relating to one’s family or to a particular person.

Dissociative fugue is characterized by a sudden, unintended, and unexpected travel to a place away from home, or workplace, or another place involved in one's daily repertoire. It is usually brief, lasting few hours to days, and is generally reversible. It is commonly associated with dissociative amnesia. In addition to amnesia, these patients may also experience confusion, trance-like behaviors, depersonalization, derealization, and conversion symptoms. It may recur in some patients.

It is important to note that dissociative fugue was deleted as a major diagnostic category in DSM-5. It is instead declared as a subtype or specifier of disso­ciative amnesia.

Treatment of dissociative amnesia and dissociative fugue is mainly with psychotherapy. 

Other options-

Option B: Confabulation refers to the unconscious filling of gaps in memory with inaccurate, fabricated, and often implausible information.

Option C: Depersonalization is defined as the persistent or recurrent feeling of detachment from one's self. The patient may report feeling like an automation or like they are watching themselves in a movie.

Option D: Dissociative identity disorder is characterized by the presence of two or more distinct identities or personality states that assume control of an individual's behavior. It was previously called multiple personality disorder. 

Related Pearl: Dissociative Disorders

DSM-5 Classification and characteristics of dissociative disorders:

Dissociative disorder
Characteristic features

Dissociative amnesia:

Failure to remember important information about oneself after a stressful event.

Amnesia usually resolves in minutes or days but may last years. Retrograde amnesia > antegrade amnesia

Dissociative fugue:

Amnesia combined with sudden wandering from home after a stressful event.

Adoption of a different identity. The patient denies memory loss during the fugue state.

Dissociative identity disorder:

Previously called multiple personality disorder.

At least two distinct personalities (“alters”) in an individual.

More common in women (particularly those sexually abused in childhood)

In a forensic setting (Eg: jail), malingering and alcohol abuse must be considered and excluded

Depersonalization disorder:

Recurrent, persistent feelings of detachment from one’s own body, the social situation, or the environment (derealisation) when stressed.

 Understanding that these perceptions are only feelings, i.e., normal reality testing.

Dissociative disorder not otherwise specified:

Dissociate symptom (Eg: trance-like state, memory loss) in - 
  • Persons exposed to intense coercive persuasion (Eg: brainwashing)
  • Indigenous to particular locations or cultures (Eg: Amok in Indonesia)
 

ICD-11 classifies Dissociative Disorders as:

  • Dissociative Identity Disorder
  • Partial Dissociative Identity Disorder
  • Depersonalization-Derealization disorder
  • Dissociative Amnesia
  • Trance Disorder
  • Possession Trance Disorder
  • Dissociative Neurological symptom disorder
  • Secondary Dissociative syndrome

questions.text: A 25-year-old obese woman comes to the clinic with complaints of multiple painful lesions associated with a foul-smelling discharge in the axilla. Examination findings are as shown in the image given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing multiple lesions with foul-smelling discharge in the intertriginous area (axilla) in an obese female is strongly suggestive of hidradenitis suppurativa.

Hidradenitis suppurativa is also called acne inversa and is seen more commonly seen after puberty. It is a chronic, inflammatory, recurrent, debilitating, follicular disease.

The following three criteria must be met for the diagnosis to be made:

  1. Typical lesions - The lesions can manifest as deep‐seated painful nodules, abscesses, draining sinuses, bridged scars, and paired or multiheaded open pseudo comedones.
  2. Typical locations - axillae, groin, perineal and perianal region, buttocks, and infra‐ and intermammary folds.
  3. Chronicity and recurrence of lesions. 

Treatment includes: 

  • General measures - lifestyle modifications such as cessation of smoking, weight loss, and general cleanliness are advised. 
  • Antibiotics - Topical clindamycin lotion 0.1% can be used to manage milder lesions. Systemic antibiotics like tetracycline and a combination of clindamycin and rifampicin can be used in such conditions.
  • Intralesional corticosteroids such a triaminolone can be used.
  • Acitretin
  • Anti-TNF alpha therapy
  • Surgery - Many lesion‐directed therapies have been identified as beneficial in the therapy of HS. Incision and drainage are done in a presence of a fluctuant abscess. Deroofing can also be done which is a tissue-saving procedure in which the roof of an abscess or sinus tract is surgically removed using either electrosurgery (using a loop) or conventional surgery. Ablative lasers and electrosurgery are also useful in removing all the involved tissues. 

Other options:

Option A: Acne vulgaris is one of the most common skin diseases, highly prevalent in adolescents. The lesions can manifest as open and closed comedones, papules, pustules, or nodules with variable degrees of inflammation and depth. The most usually affected areas are the face, back, and/or chest. These would not be found in the axillary region.

Option B: Necrobiosis lipoidica can happen at any age, it typically is seen in young adults and those in their early middle years. It is associated with diabetes. The lesion starts as a hard, dull red papule or plaque on the pretibial skin and enlarges radially to become a yellowish atrophic plaque with an erythematous edge. Telangiectatic vessels may be seen, and the surface is frequently glazed in appearance.

Option C: Pyoderma gangrenosum (PG) is a rare non‐infectious neutrophilic dermatosis. It is commonly associated with inflammatory bowel disease. The major criteria to diagnosis classical PG are a rapid progression of a painful, necrolytic cutaneous ulcer with an irregular, violaceous, and undermined border; and the elimination of any other causes of cutaneous ulceration. These lesions are usually not found in the axilla.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient came to your orthopedic clinic with complaints of pain in the hips and knees. You suspect osteoarthritis of the hips and knees and request an X-ray, findings of which are attached below. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis of her incidental finding?
questions.solution:
The incidental X-ray findings showing extensive calcification of the femoral arteries in this patient which are strongly suggestive of Monckeberg medial sclerosis. It is caused due to calcification in the medial walls of muscular arteries starting at the internal elastic lamina.

It occurs in people aged 50 years and above as a part of senile degeneration. Since the calcifications do not encroach on the vessel lumen and are usually not clinically significant. Therefore, it is usually an incidental finding as in this case. 

Histopathological examination reveals calcification that is seen as the dark purple stained area on the H&E staining as shown in the image below.

 

Other options:

Option A- Injection sclerotherapy is used for the management of varicose veins. In this technique, a detergent-like sodium tetradecyl sulfate is injected directly into the superficial veins. It destroys the venous endothelium. Following this, an elastic bandage is wrapped around the limb to cause apposition of the vessel walls. Therefore, the radiograph of the patient does not appear like the above.

Option C- Leriche's syndrome is a rare form of the aortoiliac occlusive disease which presents with a triad of intermittent claudication, erectile dysfunction, and absent femoral pulses.

Option D- Deep vein thrombosis is caused due to 3 broad categories of risk factors (Virchow's triad):

  • Hemodynamic changes (stasis or turbulence)
  • Hypercoagulability 
  • Endothelial injury

DVT most commonly occurs in the calf veins. DVT is usually asymptomatic. Some patients may present with pain in the calf or thigh. Duplex ultrasound is used in identifying venous thrombosis.

Related Pearl: Types of calcifications

  Dystrophic calcification Metastatic calcification
Location Dead and dying tissues Normal interstitial tissues of the vasculature, kidneys, lungs, and gastric mucosa.
Calcium metabolism Normal deranged causing hypercalcemia
Examples

Calcific valvular stenosis

Advanced Atheromatous plaque

Monckeberg medial sclerosis

Parathyroid tumors

Hypercalcemia of malignancy

Paget disease

vitamin D intoxication

Sarcoidosis

Renal failure

questions.text: A 4-year-old female child is currently under evaluation for supra-valvular aortic stenosis and mental retardation. A characteristic facies is present as shown in the image below. Her karyotype reveals 46XX and her blood investigations reveal hypercalcemia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette of mental retardation, elfin facies, hypercalcemia, and supravalvular aortic stenosis is strongly suggestive of Williams' syndrome.

The image shows a young girl with an elfin face with a round face, full cheeks, broad nasal bridge, anteverted nares, thick lips, and a large mouth that is usually left open. They also have short palpebral fissures, prominent ears, and a small mandible. 

It is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by multiple congenital development defects, including supra-valvular aortic stenosis, mental retardation, and an elfin facies, in association with hypercalcemia due to abnormal sensitivity to vitamin D with elevated levels of 1,25(OH)2D ranging from 150 to 500 pg/mL.

Williams' syndrome is caused due to genetic mutations involving microdeletions at the elastin locus on chromosome 7. 

Other options-

Option A: DiGeorge syndrome is caused due to deletion of chromosome 22q11.2. The characteristic features are (Mnemonic CATCH-22) Cardiac abnormality, abnormal facies, thymic aplasia, cleft palate, hypocalcemia, deletion 22q11.2.

The following image shows a child with DiGeorge syndrome:

 

Option C: Down syndrome occurs due to trisomy of chromosome 21 leading to multisystem manifestations. There is a wide range of presentations. A few key features include characteristic facies such as flat face, epicanthal folds, small head, flat nasal bridge, upward slanting palpebral fissues, brushfield spots, small nose, protruding tongue, small and lowset ears. Congenital heart defects can also be present. This patient has a normal karyotype.

The following image shows a child with Down syndrome:

 

Option D: Edward syndrome is a trisomy of chromosome 18. It is characterized by microcephaly, microphthalmia, prominent nasal bridge, coloboma of iris, microretrognathia, cleft lip, cleft palate, clenched fist with overlapping fingers, and severe growth retardation. This patient has a normal karyotype.

The following image shows a child with Edward syndrome, note the clenched fist with overlapping fingers:

Related Pearl: Clinical features of DiGeorge syndrome- Mnemonic

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

The clinical features can be remembered with the mnemonic – CATCH

  • C – Cardiac defects
  • A – Abnormal facies
  • T – Thymic aplasia
  • C – Cleft palate
  • H – Hypocalcemia

The image below shows the abnormal facies in DiGeorge syndrome.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man comes to the physician because of nasal congestion and fever for 12 days. His nasal discharge was initially clear but turned yellowish over the last few days. Over-the-counter nasal decongestants and paracetamol have not provided much relief. Examination shows purulent discharge in the nose and pharynx and tenderness over the left maxillary sinus. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with fever, purulent nasal discharge, and a tender maxillary sinus, most likely has acute sinusitis and the most appropriate management for this patient is to initiate treatment with oral amoxicillin and clavulanic acid. 

His initial symptoms of clear mucoid discharge are suggestive of acute viral rhinosinusitis, wherein reassurance and symptomatic supportive treatment would have been appropriate. It usually resolves in 7-10 days.

However, this patient's longer duration of symptoms—beyond 10 days, along with a change in the character of nasal discharge from clear to mucopurulent suggests superinfection with bacteria such as Streptococcus pneumonia or Hemophilus influenza. Bacterial rhinosinusitis necessitates treatment with antibiotics. These patients usually present with purulent nasal discharge, nasal obstruction, facial pain and tenderness, headache, and a persisting fever. 

X-ray is not recommended for the routine diagnosis of acute sinusitis as they do not change the course of management in most cases. CT scans are used when complications due to acute sinusitis such as orbital cellulitis are suspected. 

Antibiotics such as oral amoxicillin and clavulanic acid are the first-line agents. Supportive treatments such as NSAIDs, decongestants, saline irrigation, and antihistamines may be prescribed. Amphotericin B, on the other hand, is an antifungal. It is used in the treatment of pathologies such as mucormycosis and aspergillosis. 

Complications of acute maxillary sinusitis are:

  • Chronic sinusitis
  • Frontal sinusitis
  • Osteomyelitis of the maxilla
  • Orbital cellulitis: infection may spread directly through the roof of the maxilla or indirectly through the ethmoid sinus.

 

Related Pearl: Symptoms of Sinusitis

Symptoms of maxillary sinusitis:

  • Pain over the upper jaw, aggravated by stooping, coughing & chewing
  • Constitutional symptoms like malaise and fever
  • Headache in the frontal region
  • Nasal and postnasal discharge
  • Redness and edema of cheeks
  • Tenderness on pressing over the anterior wall of the antrum

Symptoms of frontal sinusitis:

  • Frontal headache/ office headache with characteristic periodicity i.e. starts early morning and gradually increases and reaches its peak by about mid-day and then starts subsiding
  • Tenderness on pressing on the floor of the frontal sinus, just above the medial canthus
  • Nasal discharge
  • Edema of the upper eyelid

Symptoms of ethmoid sinusitis:

  • Pain over the bridge of the nose and deep to the eye that is aggravated by the movements of the eyeball
  • Edema of both eyelids,
  • Nasal discharge

Symptoms of sphenoid sinusitis:

  • Headache localized to occiput or vertex
  • Postnasal discharge

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of severe joint pain on his big toe with multiple such episodes in the past. The X-ray shows the 'G' sign. Which of the following signs is also expected to be seen on ultrasound in this condition?
questions.solution:
The X-ray of this patient shows Martel's sign/ G-sign which refers to the punched-out lytic lesion and overhanging margin of the new bone. It is seen in chronic gout. Among the given options, the radiological sign that is seen in chronic gout is the double contour sign. 

Double contour sign is an ultrasound finding that is characterized by an echogenic line on the outer surface of the joint cartilage due to the deposition of monosodium urate crystals on the surface of articular cartilage.

Gout is a metabolic disease that is characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and connective tissue. It is more common in males and it usually presents as monoarthritis that may be acute and episodic or chronic. 

  • Acute gout presents with a joint that is red, hot, swollen, and extremely tender on examination. The metatarsophalangeal joint of the great toe is the most frequently involved joint.

Chronic gout may present with chronic nonsymmetric synovitis, gouty arthritis, and periarticular tophaceous deposits.

Synovial fluid analysis of joint aspirate is diagnostic and shows the following features-

  • Increased leukocyte count with a neutrophilic predominance
  • Negatively birefringent crystals on polarized light microscopy of the synovial fluid.

Other options-

Option A: Linguine sign is seen in intracapsular rupture of silicone breast implant.

Option C: The Accordion sign is seen in pseudomembranous colitis.

Option D: Water lily sign is seen in hydatid cyst.

 

Ultrasound double contour sign:

 

Negatively birefringent monosodium urate crystals-

 

The image below shows G sign:

Related Pearl: Difference between Gout and Pseudo-gout

Finding

Gout

Pseudogout

Crystal composition

Monosodium urate

Calcium pyrophosphate

Shape

Needle like

Rhomboid

Birefringence pattern

Negative

Weak positive

Most commonly affected joint

1st MTP

Knee

X-ray findings

Periarticular erosions with overhanging margins

Chondrocalcinosis

questions.text: A physician is studying parameter x. She checks the parameter x of all patients using an automated apparatus and compares them to manual checking (considered by her as the gold standard). For patient A, she finds that the automated apparatus and manual checking give very different values. However, on checking 5 times with the automated apparatus, all 5 values obtained are similar to each other. What can be concluded about the automated apparatus?
questions.solution:
The automated apparatus has low validity (accuracy) but high precision.

Validity (accuracy) refers to what extent the test accurately measures which it sets out to measure. It refers to the closeness with which measured values agree with "true" values. The values obtained by the automated apparatus are very different from the true values, reducing the validity of the automated apparatus readings.

Precision (reliability or reproducibility) is a measure of repeatability of a test. That is, the test must give consistent results when repeated more than once on the same individual or material, under the same conditions. The 5 values obtained by the automated apparatus are close to each other, making it precise.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

Related Pearl: Repeatability of a Screening Test

Repeatability is an attribute of an ideal screening test. It is also called reliability, precision, or reproducibility. It implies that the test must give consistent results when repeated on the same individual or material, under the same conditions.

It depends upon three factors:

A. Observer variation

  • All observations are subjected to variations.
  • Intra-observer variations or within-observer variations are when a single observer takes two measurements in the same subject, at the same time and obtained two different results.
  • Inter-observer variations or between-observer variations are when two different observers obtain different results on the same subject or material.
  • They are minimized by standardization of procedures, intensive training of observers, and making use of more observers.

B. Biological variation

  • It is also called subject variation.
  • They are due to changes in the parameters observed, variations in the perceptions of symptoms by patients, and regression to the mean where there is a tendency of values to be at either extreme of the distribution.

C. Errors relating to technical methods is due to the following:

  • Defective instruments
  • Erroneous calibration
  • Faulty reagents
  • Incorrect methods

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl was brought with the complaint of sudden and inappropriate outbursts of laughter for no apparent cause in the past 6 months. Her examination reveals developmental delay. Her brain MRI shows the following feature. Considering the suspected diagnosis, which other feature is most likely to be seen with this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient seems to be suffering Gelastic seizures. Her brain MRI image shows a pedunculated mass in the floor of the 3rd ventricle which is suggestive of a hypothalamic hamartoma. Thus, the other feature most likely to be seen in this condition is precocious puberty.

Precocious puberty in a girl is the appearance of any of the secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years. Precocious puberty in boys is the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 9 years. 

Hypothalamic hamartoma arises from a neuronal migration defect between 35 to 40 days of intrauterine life. They present with a classical triad of:

  • Gelastic epilepsy
  • Precocious puberty
  • Developmental delay

Other clinical features can include hypothalamic signs like diabetes insipidus, adipsia, hyperthermia, cachexia, and obesity.

A gelastic seizure is a rare type of seizure that involves a sudden burst of energy, usually in the form of laughing or crying. They have been associated classically with hypothalamic hamartomas. 

Treatment of Hypothalamic Hamartoma involves

  • GnRH agonists (depot-forms or implant) are the treatment of choice for tumor-induced central precocious puberty                 
  • In patients with hypothalamic hamartoma and associated intractable gelastic or psychomotor seizures, stereotactic radiation therapy (Gamma Knife surgery) is more effective and has fewer risks than neurosurgical intervention.

questions.text: An intern enumerates the steps to place an intercostal drainage tube in a patient. Which of the following steps is incorrect?

choices.text: Intercostal tube is to be placed along the upper border of lower rib
Identify 5th intercostal space posterior to mid axillary line to place the tube
Direct the tube posteriorly to prevent injury
Local anesthesia should include the pleura

questions.solution:
An intercostal tube is placed in the triangle of safety which is the safest site for insertion of a drain that lies in the 5th intercostal space anterior to the mid axillary line, above the level of the nipple, and, below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

Inserting and managing a chest drain.

Insertion of an intercostal tube connected to an underwater seal is the standard management.

The safest site for insertion of a chest drain is the Triangle of safety which lies:

  • Anterior to the mid-axillary line;
  • Above the level of the nipple;
  • Below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

This will be present in the fifth intercostal space.

The technique of drain insertion includes the following:

  • The area should be thoroughly sterilized before the procedure.
  • Adequate local anesthesia to include the pleura.
  • Sharp dissection should be done to cut only the skin.
  • Blunt dissection with artery forceps down through the muscle layers; which involve the serratus anterior and the intercostals.
  • An oblique tract is made, so that the skin incision and the hole in the parietal pleura do not overlie each other and so that the drain is in a short tunnel, which reduces the chance of entraining air.
  • A drain for pneumothorax and haemothorax should aim towards the apex of the lung.
  • A drain for pleural effusion or empyema should be nearer the base.
  • The drain should pass over the upper edge of the rib to avoid injury to the neurovascular bundle that lies beneath the rib. 
  • A vertical mattress suture is inserted for later wound closure. This is important for pneumothorax management but not required if the drain is for empyema (provided there is adherence of the pleura) because that tract should lie open.
  •  The drain should be connected to an underwater seal device which functions as a one-way valve.
  • After completion, check the position of the drain by taking a chest radiograph.

questions.text: A female patient with a history of psychiatric illness presents to the outpatient. She admits to abusing diuretics for the past 2 weeks. On examination, blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. With respect to extracellular fluid volume (ECF), intracellular fluid volume (ICF), and plasma sodium, which of the following changes will this patient have?

choices.text: Increased ECF, increased ICF, and decreased plasma sodium
Decreased ECF, decreased ICF, and increased plasma sodium
Decreased ECF, increased ICF, and decreased plasma sodium
Increased ECF, decreased ICF, and increased plasma sodium

questions.solution:
Diuretic overuse shows decreased ECF, increased ICF, and decreased plasma sodium, leading to hypoosmotic volume contraction.

A similar picture is seen in adrenal insufficiency. Due to a deficiency of aldosterone, there is a decrease in both plasma volume and osmolality.

Other Options:

Option A: This is seen in cases of hypoosmotic volume expansion like in the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) and bronchogenic tumors. 

SIADH is associated with euvolemic hyponatremia. This leads to a decrease in the osmolarity of the ECF. This causes a fluid shift from the ECF to the ICF until the osmolarity of both compartments becomes equal. The fluid influx also leads to a decrease in the ICF's osmolarity. Therefore, the net effect is an increase in extracellular volume, an increase in intracellular volume, and a fall in osmolarity in both compartments.

Option B: This is seen in cases of hyperosmotic volume contraction like in diabetes insipidus and excessive sweating.

Option D: This is seen in cases of hyperosmotic volume expansion like in high NaCl intake. The addition of excess NaCl to ECF pulls the fluid from ICF into the ECF. This results in a decreased volume of ICF, increased volume of ECF, and increased osmolarity in both ECF and ICF.

The illustration given below shows the Darrow-Yannet diagram in various conditions.

Related Pearl: Distribution of body fluids

Plasma proteins

Burns

No change

questions.text: What is the correct statement regarding the wound indicated by the red arrow in the given image of the skull?

choices.text: It is an entry wound because the outer table appears bevelled
It is an Exit wound because the inner table appears bevelled
It is an Exit wound because the outer table appears bevelled
It is an entry wound because the inner table appears bevelled

questions.solution:
In the given image, bevelling is seen on the outer table and a punched out hole is seen on the inner table. So, it is an exit wound.

Entry wound: The initial contact of the missile punches a clean hole through the outer table of the skull. Where the bullet emerges internally, the inner table is then unsupported and a cone-shaped plug is detached, forming a crater that is appreciably larger than the external hole.

  • Bevelling: inner table
  • Punched out hole: outer table

Exit wound: If the bullet traverses the cranium and penetrates the opposite side, the same pattern occurs, this time with the small hole on the inner table and the crater on the outside.

  • Bevelling: outer table
  • Punched out hole: inner table

A 'rat-hole' appearance of the entry wound of a shotgun can be seen from 30 cm to 5 meters of range:

  • Circular rat-hole wound without peripheral satellite pellet holes is seen in 30cm-1m range.
  • Central rat-hole wound with peripheral satellite pellet holes is seen in 1m-5m range.

Ricochet: This is when the bullet hits an intervening object before hitting the desired target. Due to this, it tumbles towards the target and enters it obliquely, rather than head-on.

Related Pearl: Difference between Wound of Entry and Exit

Characteristics

Wound of entry

Wound of exit

Size

Smaller than the diameter of the bullet.

In close discharge, skin is torn, hence size is increased.

Bigger than the diameter of the bullet.

Margin

Inverted

Everted

Soiling of wound

+ve

-ve

Abrasion collar

+ve

-ve

+ve

-ve

+ve

-ve

Bleeding

More

+ve

-ve

Dispersion of pallets (shotgun)

+ve

-ve

-ve

+ve

Bright red (Carboxy Hb)

+ve (Near shot)

-ve

X-ray Metallic Ring

+ve

-ve

+ve (contact shot)

-ve

Blast effect

+ve (contact shot)

-ve

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose. She also complains of blurry vision and headache. On examination, erythema, edema, and a few black, necrotic areas are seen. The diagnosis is made and treatment is started immediately, with the first line drug indicated. Which of the following adverse effects is not classically seen due to the drug used?
questions.solution:
This diabetic patient with nasal discharge, eye pain and necrotic areas most likely has mucormycosis. The drug of choice is amphotericin B. The adverse effects of amphotericin B include: An acute febrile reaction (fever, chills, rash), nephrotoxicity, normocytic anemia, and hypokalemia.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: You have been allotted a patient with an upper limb fracture in the orthopedics ward. The patient fell on his elbow and complains of pain on elbow movement. On examining, the 3 bony point relationship is reversed. The examiner gives you xrays as shown below and asks you to pick up the one belonging to the patient.
questions.solution:
The given patient with a fall on the elbow and reversed 3 bony point relationship is likely a case of Olecranon fracture. The x-ray D corresponds to the displaced transverse olecranon fracture.

The three bony points are the tip of the medial epicondyle, the tip of the lateral epicondyle and the olecranon. When the elbow is in 90 degrees of flexion, they form an isosceles triangle. When the elbow is extended, they lie transversely in a straight line. 

Since supracondylar fracture (X-ray: C) occurs above any of these bony landmarks, the 3 bony point relationship is preserved in this.

Other options:

A - Galeazzi fracture 

B - Monteggia fracture

C- Supracondylar fracture

 

Related Pearl: Three point bony relationship in elbow:

The three bony points in the elbow are :

  • Tip of the medial epicondyle
  • Tip of the lateral epicondyle
  • Olecranon

When the elbow is in 90 degrees of flexion, these points form an isosceles triangle. When the elbow is extended, they lie transversely in a straight line.

The three-point bony relationship is maintained in the case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.

Conditions where it is distorted:

  • Fracture medial condyle and epicondyle
  • Fracture lateral condyle and epicondyle
  • Intercondylar fracture of humerus
  • Fracture olecranon
  • Elbow dislocation

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text:
The actions of the muscle attached to the area marked by the red arrow are:

1. Depression of mandible
2. Protrusion of mandible
3. Side to side movement of the jaw.
4. Elevation of mandible
5. Retraction of mandible
questions.solution:
The marked area is pterygoid fovea where the lateral pterygoid muscle is inserted. The action of this muscle is depression, protrusion, and side to side movement of the jaw.

In addition, lateral pterygoid muscle is inserted into the articular disc and capsule of TMJ.

The lateral pterygoid has the following actions:

  1. Opening of the jaw (depression): Lateral pterygoid has a specialized role in mandibular opening mediated by its horizontal fibres. When left and right lateral pterygoid muscles contract together, the mandibular condyle is pulled forwards and slightly downwards. This protrusive movement alone has little or no function except in assisting the opening the jaw (Gray's Anatomy 41st edition).
  2. Side-to-side movement: When the lateral pterygoid contracts unilaterally along with the adjacent medial pterygoid the jaw is pulled medially. This is used for grinding food between teeth of the same side. This action is mediated by the inferior head of lateral pterygoid.

Masseter muscle:

  • Origin - It arises from a thick aponeurosis from the maxillary process of zygomatic bone and zygomatic arch.
  • Insertion - It inserted into the lateral surface of ramus of the mandible and coronoid process



Temporalis muscle:

  • Origin - It arises from the temporal fossa and deep surface of temporal fascia.
  • Insertion - It is inserted into the coronoid process and to the anterior border of the ramus of the mandible up to the third molar tooth.

Lateral pterygoid muscle:

  • Origin - Upper head arises from the infratemporal surface and infratemporal crest of the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. The lower head arises from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate. 
  • Insertion - It is inserted into the pterygoid fovea, capsule of the temporomandibular joint, and articular disc.

 Medial pterygoid muscle:

  • Origin - Deep head arises from medial surface of lateral pterygoid plate and pyramidal process of palatine bone. Superficial head arises from the maxillary tuberosity and pyramidal process of palatine bone
  • Insertion- It is inserted into the medial surface of the ramus, near the angle of mandible

Note:

  • Among the four mastication muscles (temporalis, masseter, medial pterygoid, lateral pterygoid), the lateral pterygoid is the only muscle that helps in depression/opening of the jaw. 
  • The main jaw opener muscles are digastric and geniohyoid

 

Muscles of mastication

Mandibular nerve (CN V3)

Related Pearl: Muscles of mastication

questions.text: What is the correct sequence followed while doing rapid sequence induction?

choices.text: Preoxygenation  -> IV succinylcholine -> Propofol IV -> Intubate
Preoxygenation -> Propofol IV -> Intubate  -> IV succinylcholine
Preoxygenation -> Propofol IV -> IV succinylcholine -> Intubate
IV succinylcholine -> Preoxygenation  -> Propofol IV -> Intubate

questions.solution:
The correct order of rapid sequence induction (RSI) is: Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen -> Administer IV induction agent -> IV succinylcholine -> Do not ventilate -> Direct laryngoscopy and intubation -> Confirm endotracheal tube placement -> Remove cricoid pressure.

RSI is done when the patient is at increased risk of pulmonary aspiration as in pregnancy, full stomach, intestinal obstruction, hiatus hernia, encephalopathy, morbid obesity, and diabetic gastroparesis.

Bag and mask ventilation is avoided in rapid sequence intubation (RSI) because it leads to stomach inflation and increases risk of aspiration.
